I gave XCom 2 a thumbs up as the developers did an excellent technical job with their creation. The game looks great, sounds great, and plays great but the problem I have with the game is the same issue I have with most of these turn-based combat grid systems. Once I select my characters and builds, I find myself going into every mission with the same tactics. In other words, just going through the motions which becomes very tedious after awhile. 

The one thing that kept me motivated was the story which is obviously based on the 1980's TV show "V". The narrative is great and tapped hard into my 80' nostalgia but there simply was not enough supporting content inbetween missions to sustain my interest once the combat began to feel repetitive.

You can look at other reviews for detailed reviews but all I will say is that reviving the old format of XCOM and putting it in this art style revolutionized top-down gaming. It will be almost 10 years now and this game still holds up really well. It desperately needs a sequel, Firaxis, please at least try.

XCOM 2 is a successor to both the ups and downs of Enemy Unknown, and it shows in its design. Firaxis directly compensated for many of the most popular complaints people had about playing EU, and while that flattened some of the highs, it also brought up some of the lows. For the average player, it's a significant net gain. For hardcore players, you'll need to turn to mods to achieve something as wondrous as Long War 1, or just to fix up all your gripes with the vanilla game; in order to make things more reliably enjoyable, some replayability was sacrificed by scripting the experience more behind the scenes. You won't notice this on your first playthrough, but play enough and it'll be clear too many things feel the same each time.
This is why XCOM 2 is a much better game for the average XCOM player - someone who plays it for a couple weeks, or maybe just one full campaign at most, enjoys it, and never touches it again. For those of us who live and breathe this series, the sameyness between repeated campaigns becomes apparent, but can be solved with mods, and that is XCOM 2's greatest improvement for us - it is extremely mod-friendly compared to EU. The steam workshop is absolutely bursting with entries, and you'll be hard pressed to find any other turn-based game with this many mods created for it. Thank you to all the modders who've given this game so much life.

But to be honest, if you're the kind of person affected by all that, you already know about XCOM 2 and have likely played it to death already. For those of you who actually need this review to decide whether to try this or not - do try it. It doesn't reinvent the wheel of EU, just builds on it in deep ways befitting a true sequel, and if you like these kinds of games you're near guaranteed to have a great time. The massive moddability is a blessing and curse - just like Skyrim, you can practically turn this game into whatever kind of modded overhaul you want, but just like Skyrim, expect to lose hours and hours putting together such modlists. There's a reason I still play EU as well - when I want a great package that Just Works, I play EU + Long War. When I want more, that's when I come back to XCOM 2.

Thanks again to Firaxis and 2K for such a wonderful game, again.

Coming from the Mass Effect franchise from hour one, I basically found the atmosphere in this game pretty alike from the storytelling. First upfront: I didn't play with mods, I never played XCOM 1 but I played a lot of games like that I wasn't frustrated with half that much, not even on peak cases. Not only dated back to Commandos, ect, but also one "more recent" example I still measure other games on would be Phantom Doctrine. Same game rule set with tiles and turns, a hit chance, - that doesn't make you question if for the programmer 1+1 is 2 also - a slightly more intelligent options to handle overwatch directions and yet challenging still. And if you wanted, you turn up difficulty still, without needing you to reload because of every minimal enemy encounter. But let's first get to the ups first and best-possible-objectively [u]fair[/u]...

The pro share:
- Immersive story telling. 
- Variation of localisation and VA is well picked. At least from the limited VA's I tested.
- Demi-Free Campaign leaves an impression of being in charge of the direction, even if it's only an illusion, it works so far.
- Lot of research and upgrade-potential for equipment.
- The "biotic" class as I call it from Mass Effect has a nice vibe to the sister-franchise (atmosphere wise).
- The cutscenes between the missions are repetitive, but still they're done in a way you still don't rly wanna skip them. Also the camera cuts in-fight are nicely done to give the impression of a dynamic and action in the skirmish going on.
- The Threat aka avatar project as a main mission pressure point brings a nice overall-tension with it and if you're mindful, you can somewhat get a hand on slowing it down as much as possible.

That might sounds like a lot. And if you have your most vital points checkmarked in a game like this, go and buy it. But I recommend to hear out the cons first to be warned about what's ahead. Bc as you know, this isn't a recommendation feedback for a reason. And that's not primarily about Take 2's crap policy lastly, - despite them deserving it to be cancelled only for that - it's more the stuff ingame that strips the overall gameplay the long term fun and makes it tedious and energy consuming instead of giving a great experience. And you can see, the points are 'weighty'. So let's get to the...

The Con share:
- It's a "human resources" shooter: The game clearly aims to bury your characters alive, so you better get used to the fact you have no characters but meat on legs, bc the moment you give them a name and background is the moment your problems start with this game, because you want certain characters to live and survive, but the game does have exorbit-hard difficulty jumps on some missions that you ultimately lose people, if you don't reload on every yet-so-small mistake you do but can't foresee, because some things the game doesn't tell you upfront and the fog of war is nothing else but a "surprise-you're-frakked"-courtain most of the time.

- Uber-super-exaggerating-much elite-enemies: If you're new to this game and don't know anything about what's going on and how the game expects you to handle it, you'Re basically borked already, but don't know it in the early hours yet, because it's a problem if a game turns out to become crappy by midgame and while you're still able to refund it. At least that seemed to be the Devs' POV. Point being: The Boss mechanics are ridiculous. Having an already overpowered enemy on the battlefield with 500% of your highest soldier's health, a good armor rating and the special ability to act "every in-between action you do with one soldier alone" is a bit of an overkill. I can understand the case of them being very sturdy, fine. But always the exaggerating "super-nemesis" based on an imaginary power level you barely reach, if you're not on drugs, or playing by guides only. But playing by guides only is not playing a game, it's stupid assembly line working to progress to the end and being able to say "I got a savegame that finished the game too". These elite enemy mechanics trait to be able to act in every turn have no counter spell and they're using skills with that much AOE that you're losing very likely all your high skilled team members and stuff only because of such encounters. This is one of the most frustrating things you can offer in a game and that's a dead end. There's no discussion on that, because base games should not be measured on hardcore RPG rules, which clearly this game tries to be. I've been playing and monitoring games since mid 90's, so don't piss in my ear and tell me it's raining, folks.

- Hit Chance. Yeah, problem is, with all the games having had a hit chance that delivered (mostly, as in being a chance) what it promised, it is - in the very end - no real hit chance. I know: People have been discussing this a lot and I have read a lot of ego talk or fanboy-dom out of it instead of being reasonable analysing it. Fact is, I don't care about your camp wars, I'm here to make my own mind, so I tested it on long term before I even knew there was a camp war about this going on long ago. So trusting my own 'demi-scientific' - aka best possible repeatable-same circumstances - experiments I did a test that was anything but a rocket science! Srsly, everyone could do it, just don't go astray on the repetitive tests.
Means => Make a savegame with a shot of 60% hit chance, do the shot and reload the exact savegame over and over again. Make notes on how often you hit on a minimum of 20 times and multiplicate it with a factor of five. Then tell me you've got a hit chance reflecting a 60% likeliness to hit something in this game. I didn't want to believe it, but I had a case in an unmodded (base) game in which I reloaded the game 30 times with always the same 64% of hit chance. And it missed every single time. I mean, this is insane, right? Not one hit. What exactly is one to think about that, I ask everyone claiming math in this game being this or that? I mean, how's that even possible? I even changed the parameters after this by doing another action after save then to see if it's a case of PRNG, as developers claim, but it didn't change a single case. The hit chance in this game is everything else BUT truthful or accurate. It may be mathematical, but that means basically [i]everything and nothing[/i], as it only says something gets calculated, but hit chance rating displayed and true-hit-chance are not even playing in the same league in this game. It though seems half of the time accurate enough so it gives an impression of being reliable. But it's not. And with over 30 times of reloading and 20 more with changed order of orders, nobody is able to call it "bad luck" anymore. This is intentionally rendered a hardcore RPG mechanic to go against the player. That simple and not the first game that time frame to go that way.

- REELOAD-Doctrine! Aka "Savegame shooter": You only have a fair chance, if you know where the enemies are and WHEN the enemies are there. So scouting is s joke at the second you do shoot the very first time and the first-move reaction from enemies jumping to cover can turn out to be your coffin's nail, if it's the last movement in your turn you made while uncovering them. So REELOAD it is. If the games wasn't so annoyingly out to put you on a time pressure in turns half the missions, this wouldn't be a solid negative point. But it is, so here we are.

- 2K. Bc it's the longest point I put it at the end of the list, even if it belongs on the top with a huge spotlight show on it to tell the world about this atrocity! Selling personal data is a no-go and everyone doing so belongs on the banish list forever. This is breach of trust between customer and the one stealing data from your PC on a demi-legal way. Walk of shame ahead.

Is there a fix for this mess?
Only if you can find a way to disarm some of those game(?) breaking(!) points above in the cons-section. Sadly there are no mods to fix it all.
